rev.diff:
Line 45: Line 45:
==History==
==History==
  +
{{unreferencedsection|date=January 2008}}
  +
Originally founded in 1839 as the "Home for the Relief of Aged Indigent Black Persons" by a group of prominent philanthropists led by Mrs. John Jay, the hospital's function gradually became the most important aspect of the operation.{{fact}} In 1882, the name was changed to "The Colored Home and Hospital."{{fact}}
Originally founded in 1839 as the "Home for the Relief of Aged Indigent Black Persons" by a group of prominent philanthropists led by Mrs. John Jay, the hospital's function gradually became the most important aspect of the operation.{{fact}} In 1882, the name was changed to "The Colored Home and Hospital."{{fact}}
Line 54: Line 56:
==Lincoln medical center today==
==Lincoln medical center today==
  +
{{refimprovesect|date=January 2008}}
In 1976, a new facility was dedicated about two miles from the "Old Lincoln," at a construction cost of 220 million dollars.{{fact}} The present hospital building incorporates some of the most advanced concepts in hospital design and sophisticated equipment.{{fact}} It occupies five full city blocks, providing health care to the entire South Bronx community, as well as parts of Upper Manhattan.{{fact}} Lincoln also administers the Substance Abuse Division, located at 349 East 140th Street.{{fact}}
In 1976, a new facility was dedicated about two miles from the "Old Lincoln," at a construction cost of 220 million dollars.{{fact}} The present hospital building incorporates some of the most advanced concepts in hospital design and sophisticated equipment.{{fact}} It occupies five full city blocks, providing health care to the entire South Bronx community, as well as parts of Upper Manhattan.{{fact}} Lincoln also administers the Substance Abuse Division, located at 349 East 140th Street.{{fact}}
